Package mainCalculatorPackage

Class BusinessLogic

  • java.lang.Object
    • mainCalculatorPackage.BusinessLogic
  • public class BusinessLogic
extends java.lang.Object

    Title: BusinessLogic Class.

    Description: The code responsible for performing the calculator business logic functions. This method deals with CalculatorValues and performs actions on them. The class expects data from the User Interface to arrive as Strings and returns Strings to it. This class calls the CalculatorValue class to do computations and this class knows nothing about the actual representation of CalculatorValues, that is the responsibility of the CalculatorValue class and the classes it calls.

    Copyright: Lynn Robert Carter Â© 2017

    Version:
    4.00 2014-10-18 The JavaFX-based GUI implementation of a long integer calculator, 4.10 2018-01-15 The implementation of integer subtraction, multiplication and division is done., 4.20 2018-02-02 The Square Root method initialized with change in error meassages., 4.30 2018-02-25 Implementation of FSM to provide high quality error messages., 4.40 2018-03-15 Implementation of error terms calculation and respective high quality error Messages., 4.50 2018-04-13 Implementation of Estimated Measured Values and Error Terms with respect to digits of significance., 5.10 2018-10-04 Implementation of UNumber Library to provide unlimited precision. Currently the precision is set to 25 significant digits., 5.20 2018-11-22 Implementation of Unit Support System with Signal Normalization as well as Inter-Conversion of Units of Same Physical Dimensions. Version 5.20 is designed and implemented keeping Hohmann Transfer Equations and Respective Calculations in consideration., 6.00 2019-02-24 Updated for supporting the Programmable Calculator UI
    Author:
    Lynn Robert Carter, JSGREWAL, Sumit, Shivam

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      BusinessLogic()
      This method initializes all of the elements of the business logic aspect of the calculator.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BusinessLogic

        public BusinessLogic()
        This method initializes all of the elements of the business logic aspect of the calculator. There is no special computational initialization required, so the initialization of the attributes above are all that are needed.

      • setOperand1

        public boolean setOperand1​(java.lang.String value,
                           java.lang.String errorTermS,
                           java.lang.String unit)
                    throws java.lang.NumberFormatException
        This public method takes an input String, checks to see if there is a non-empty input string. If so, it places the converted CalculatorValue into operand1, any associated error message into operand1ErrorMessage, and sets flags accordingly.
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:
        True if the set did not generate an error; False if there was invalid input
        Throws:
        java.lang.NumberFormatException

The logic of this method is the same as that for operand1 above.

The logic of this method is similar to that for operand1 above. (There is no defined flag.)

      • getOperand1Defined

        public boolean getOperand1Defined()
        This public getter fetches the defined attribute for operand1. You can't use the lack of an error message to know that the operand is ready to be used. An empty operand has no error associated with it, so the class checks to see if it is defined and has no error before setting this flag true.
        Returns:
        true if the operand is defined and has no error, else false

      • getOperand2Defined

        public boolean getOperand2Defined()
        This public getter fetches the defined attribute for operand2. You can't use the lack of an error message to know that the operand is ready to be used. An empty operand has no error associated with it, so the class checks to see if it is defined and has no error before setting this flag true.
        Returns:
        true if the operand is defined and has no error, else false

      • getErrorTerm1Defined

        public boolean getErrorTerm1Defined()
        This public getter fetches the defined attribute for ErrorTerm 1. You can't use the lack of an error message to know that the error term is ready to be used. An empty error term has no error associated with it, so the class checks to see if it is defined and has no error before setting this flag true.
        Returns:
        true if the error term is defined and has no error, else false

      • getErrorTerm2Defined

        public boolean getErrorTerm2Defined()
        This public getter fetches the defined attribute for ErrorTerm 2. You can't use the lack of an error message to know that the error term is ready to be used. An empty error term has no error associated with it, so the class checks to see if it is defined and has no error before setting this flag true.
        Returns:
        true if the error term is defined and has no error, else false

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        This toString method invokes the toString method of the result type (CalculatorValue is this case) to convert the value from its hidden internal representation into a String, which can be manipulated directly by the BusinessLogic and the UserInterface classes.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
